image.altText: A court build with a columned verandah and a blue coloured building behind

props.synopsis: A lawyer whose experience of sexual harassment prompted the dismissal of a South Australian magistrate doubts the findings of a second review of the legal profession will spark immediate change.

title.children: Sexual harassment still ‘systemic’ in legal profession, says lawyer

image.altText: A giant burrowing cockroach resting on its back in cupped hands

props.synopsis: While people pay good money to get rid of cockroaches and other creepy-crawlies, Kris Messenger has dedicated her life to spruiking the benefits of bugs. But she says demand for them as pets can have an impact on ecosystems if they are poached from the wild.

title.children: This $80 native cockroach is a popular pet, but there's a dark side to the industry

image.altText: Aldgate telecommunications tower

props.synopsis: Regional customers in South Australia, including the Adelaide Hills, say their mobile phone and internet services have been patchy at best since 3G was switched off.

title.children: Residents in high-risk bushfire zone fear 3G switch-off will stop alerts

image.altText: Pizza on a cutting board.

props.synopsis: A franchisee running more than a dozen Domino's pizza outlets in two states has been banned from employing trainees and apprentices at 12 SA stores, after an investigation by a workplace watchdog.

title.children: Domino's pizza franchisee banned from hiring trainees across 12 SA stores

image.altText: Sexual abuse victim

props.synopsis: A child sex abuse survivor has urged other victims to come forward after her abuser — a former South Australian police officer and her then-stepfather — was jailed for four years.

title.children: Child abuse survivor speaks out after ex-cop stepfather jailed

image.altText: A sign in an outback town which says "Welcome to Oodnadatta, Australia's hottest driest town."

props.synopsis: Residents of Oodnadatta, one of Australia's hottest towns, have suffered through two power outages this week as temperatures soared above 40 degrees Celsius.

title.children: Power outages hit one of Australia's hottest towns as temps soar above 40

image.altText: an old photograph of women working in an old telephone exchange, with basic computers and panels.

props.synopsis: Gone are the days of manually plugging in cords to connect phone calls but the memories remain for a group of women who brought people closer together.

title.children: Telephonists reminisce 40 years on from secrets, party lines and cyclones

image.altText: An old stone building with a red dome

props.synopsis: The 39-year-old father was sentenced to more than three years in the District Court after previously pleading guilty to a charge of arson for causing "extensive damage" to the home, in Adelaide's north.

title.children: Father jailed for torching family home in act of 'domestic abuse'

image.altText: Javier Romo celebarates

props.synopsis: Spanish rider Javier Romo Oliver out-thought his major rivals and Tour Down Under favourites to claim a maiden professional victory on stage three into Uraidla.

title.children: Spanish surprise as Romo rolls favourites to lead Tour Down Under

image.altText: An aerial view showing land with trees and the ocean.

props.synopsis: The South Australian government has approved a plan for a $330 million desalination plant to address projected water shortages by 2026, but not everyone is happy.

title.children: Water is set to run out in this region. Why do some reject a proposed fix?

image.altText: A caucasian man with olive skin and black hair walks through dense greenery with a subtle smile towards the camera

props.synopsis: Organic certification is not legally required for a product to be described as organic, but a business making organic claims must be able to prove them. Some producers say a national standard would give consumers full transparency.

title.children: What is labelled organic on shelves could change under a proposed bill

image.altText: A boy stands next to an emu statue made of metal scraps

props.synopsis: George Williams has managed to give discarded farm parts a new life while living and learning on a remote cattle station.

title.children: 10yo welder makes winning sculptures from outback scraps

image.altText: A long, sparkling swimming pool runs between manicured gardens towards a row of villas in bright sunlight.

props.synopsis: Balinese authorities have finally had enough and sent hundreds of police to shut down a luxury villa complex known to locals as the "Russian village" after years of simmering tension and suspicion about building permit violations.

title.children: Hundreds of Balinese police shut down luxury 'Russian village'

image.altText: Peter Dutton speaks at a press conference with David Littleproud behind him

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton has shut down his Nationals counterpart's suggestion that Australia should "lean into" the gender debate, after Donald Trump's executive order rejecting recognition of transgender people in the United States.

title.children: Peter Dutton shuts down Nationals leader's call to 'lean into' gender debate

image.altText: On stage, Samuel Barnett stands smiling, nervously smiling and holding a mic to his mouth, in front of a red curtain.

props.synopsis: It took more than a decade for British Brazilian Australian playwright Marcelo Dos Santos to have his big break with Feeling Afraid as If Something Terrible Is Going to Happen.

title.children: After years of hustle, this Aussie writer broke through with 'gay Fleabag'

image.altText: Danni-Wyatt Hodge stretches as Alana King fields

props.synopsis: Australia keeps its Women's Ashes winning streak alive with the DLS method delivering a six-run victory for the home side over England.

title.children: England left fuming as rain helps Australia win second Women's Ashes T20

image.altText: Emerson Jones hits a flying backhand.

props.synopsis: Emerson Jones is the world number one junior, and the rising star has been compared to former Australian tennis great Ash Barty.

title.children: Why Aussie teen Jones is 'one of the best young players we've seen'

image.altText: Green plant and smoke in front of brown curtain

props.synopsis: The flower has been said to smell like rotting flesh, wet socks or hot cat food, and only stinks for 24 hours after blooming.

title.children: Putricia the stinky corpse flower blooms in Sydney's Botanic Gardens

image.altText: General view of the Olympic rings on Eiffel Tower Stadium.

props.synopsis: There is a push for the IOC to better compensate athletes and give them more input into decisions that affect their careers, including sponsorship freedom.

title.children: Calls grow for Olympians to receive greater compensation from IOC

image.altText: An older man looking dour while wearing a suit with a blue tie, and his top button undone

props.synopsis: A psychiatrist resigning in protest over the lack of resources in NSW's mental health sector says the state government's response is effectively a declaration of war.

title.children: NSW premier should be called before coroner, resigning psychiatrist says

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

image.altText: Woman with wide brimmed hat stands on a lawn.

props.synopsis: Police wrap up a nine-month investigation into the alleged sexual assault of former Labor MP Brittany Lauga at a Yeppoon pub last year.

title.children: No charges laid over alleged sexual assault of former Queensland MP

image.altText: A man wearing a camo hat smiles with a woman in front of a pier

props.synopsis: NSW Police investigate whether criminals involved in some of Sydney’s anti-Semitic attacks were hired by an underworld network in exchange for payment.

title.children: Man says he was acting under duress when he set fire to Bondi brewery

image.altText: Thousands of jellyish in the water

props.synopsis: The spectacle of thousands of jellyfish at Hobart's waterfront dock may be breathtaking, but a leading scientist has warned their presence indicates something in the environment is out of balance.

title.children: Jellyfish invasion in Hobart means something awry, scientist says

image.altText: A man in a suit and tie

props.synopsis: Former Liberal Party staffer Bruce Lehrmann will ask for a judge-only trial as he seeks to defend himself against two charges of rape.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann seeks judge-only trial over rape charges

image.altText: Princess Diana in a purple suit sits smiling next to a young Prince Harry dressed in a suit and tie

props.synopsis: News Group Newspapers expressed regret to Harry for intruding into his mother's life "in particular during his younger years".

title.children: Diana would be 'rightly proud' of Harry's tenacity to take on Murdoch tabloids

image.altText: Shoppers outside Myer's store at Chadstone in Melbourne

props.synopsis: Shareholders of Myer and Premier Investments have both overwhelmingly voted in favour of a deal that will see the department store acquire fashion chains including Just Jeans, Dotti and Jay Jays.

title.children: Myer seals 'one of the most significant' deals with Premier merger

image.altText: A truck and the mangled ruins of other vehicles next to a country highway.

props.synopsis: Melbourne man Christopher Joannidis, 30, was pulled over by police moments before causing the fatal pile-up in northern Victoria in 2023.

title.children: Jail for Mercedes driver who caused five deaths while on way to wedding

image.altText: A large crowd watches King Gizzard play live at Splendour In The Grass 2023.

props.synopsis: The long-running music festival won't return for 2025, but organisers promise it will "come back bigger and better when the time is right".

title.children: Splendour In The Grass confirms it won't return for 2025

image.altText: Donald Trump in a blue suit, white shirt and red tie smirking while standing in front of a brown door with white framing

props.synopsis: The United States president pardoned the founder of the underground illicit drugs marketplace, as part of a raft of sweeping announcements during the first two days of his new administration.

title.children: Why Trump pardoned Silk Road creator a decade after life imprisonment

image.altText: Donald and Melania Trump wearing floral necklaces.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump has already taken radical new stances on Greenland and the Panama Canal. What do security experts predict he'll do in the Pacific?

title.children: Australia's neighbours 'central to competition with China' for Trump, experts say

image.altText: cargo ship traverses the Agua Clara Locks of the Panama Canal in Colon, Panama

props.synopsis: Donald Trump would have no recourse under international law if he decided to make a play for the passage, and Panama's president has rejected the US president's words, saying no nation "interferes with our administration".

title.children: Why Trump says he wants to take back control of the Panama Canal

image.altText: A blue Meta logo placed on the keyboard of a silver laptop

props.synopsis: Meta denies that Instagram and Facebook users were forced to follow Donald Trump and JD Vance after the inauguration.

title.children: You might be following Trump on social media without meaning to

image.altText: A black cloud of smoke advances over yellow grassland with a fire line visible.

props.synopsis: More than 31,000 people have been ordered to evacuate, and another 23,000 are under evacuation warnings from the path of the fire around Castaic Lake.

title.children: New wildfire breaks out north of Los Angeles
